page.title: Simulation with AnyLogic/Pedestrian Simulation/Step 4. Configuring the simulation

revision.comment: +category
revision.text:
==Step 4. Configuring Simulation==
Model simulation has a set of specific settings. A group of model settings is called an experiment, and experiments are displayed at the bottom of the model branch in the workspace tree. You can create several experiments for the same model with alternative model settings. One experiment is created by default and named ''Simulation''.
[[File:Step 4. Configuring the simulation 1.png]]
If we start the model, it will work for 100 time units and then will stop. Since we want to observe the process for a long time, we need to remove the model stop condition.
[[File:Step_1._Creating_a_new_model1.gif]] '''Remove the model stop condition''' #In the '''Project''' view, click the ''Simulation:Main'' experiment item. #Go to the '''Model Time''' tab of the '''Properties''' window. Here you can define model time settings. In Pedestrian Library a model time unit is considered as one day of a model lifetime (you can see that ''days'' are chosen as '''Time units'''). #Choose '''Never''' in the '''Stop''' drop-down list. The model now will simulate infinitely until we will stop it.</br>[[File:Step 4. Configuring the simulation 2.png]]
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Simulation with AnyLogic/Pedestrian Simulation/Step 5. Running the model

revision.comment: +category
revision.text:
==Step 5. Running the Model==
We have finished creating a simple model using AnyLogic Pedestrian Library. Now you can run the model.
Build your model by clicking the '''Build Model''' [[File:Step_7._Running_the_model.gif‎]] toolbar button. If there are some errors in your model, the building fails and the '''Problems''' view appears listing all the errors found in your model. Double-click an error in the list to open the location of the error and fix it.
[[File:Step 5. Running the model 1.png|none|frame|''Problems view'']]
After the model is successfully built, you can start it. Running the simulation, you automatically bring the current model up to date.
[[File:Step_1._Creating_a_new_model1.gif]] '''Start the model''' #Click the '''Run''' [[File:Step_7._Running_the_model2.gif‎]] toolbar button and choose the experiment you want to run from the drop-down list. Your simulation experiment is called <tt>Subway Entrance/Simulation</tt>.</br>[[File:Step 5. Running the model 2.png]]</br>In the case this model is the only one opened in the workspace at the moment you will be prompted to run this particular experiment. Later on this button will start the previously run experiment. To run any other experiment, right-click the experiment in the '''Project''' view and choose '''Run''' from the context menu.
Having started the model, you will see the presentation window. It displays the presentation designed for your simulation experiment.
[[File:Step 5. Running the model 3.png]]
Click the button to '''Run the model and switch to Main view''' and observe the process you have modeled. You can see that the model behaves correct: passengers enter the subway entrance and pass through the corridor leading to the subway trains.
[[File:Step 5. Running the model 4.png]]
You can adjust the execution speed to your needs using '''Slow down''' and '''Speed up''' [[File:Step_7._Running_the_model_4.png]] toolbar buttons. You can also switch to virtual time mode to view simulation run at its maximum speed and simulate a long period of time. To enable virtual time mode click the '''Toggle real/virtual time mode''' [[File:Step 5. Running the model 5.png]] toolbar button.
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Simulation with AnyLogic/Pedestrian Simulation/Step 6. Adding ticket control gates

revision.comment: +category
revision.text:
==Step 6. Adding Ticket Control Gates==
Now we will expand our model by adding automatic ticket control gates. Thus we will show you how services are defined in Pedestrian Library.
First, we will modify our animation and then modify the model flowchart.
[[File:Step_1._Creating_a_new_model1.gif]] '''Modify the model animation''' #Draw four lines representing ticket control gates as shown in the figure below.</br>[[File:Step 6. Adding ticket control gates 1.png]] #The starting point is important. Passengers will move from the stating to the ending point of a line. #Create a group containing all these lines drawn. We need it since we want to define a service with several shapes.</br>Select four just created lines (the easiest way to select several shapes is to subsequently click on them with '''Ctrl''' pressed), right-click the selection and choose '''Grouping/Create a group''' from the popup menu. You will see a group icon [[File:Step 6. Adding ticket control gates 2.png]] appeared in the center of the selection. Select this group and rename it to <tt>gatesGroup</tt>. #Draw polylines animating queues to ticket control gates as shown in the figure below:</br>[[File:Step 6. Adding ticket control gates 3.png]] #The starting point of the polyline is important. It stands for the head of the queue. Therefore place the first point of each polyline near the corresponding ticket control gate. #Add all just created polylines to a new group as you did it recently for the lines representing control gates. Name this group <tt>gatesQueuesGroup</tt>. #Draw a line as shown in the figure below. Name it <tt>lineBeforeGates</tt>.</br>[[File:Step 6. Adding ticket control gates 4.png]]
Now we will modify the model flowchart.
[[File:Step_1._Creating_a_new_model1.gif]] '''Modify the model flowchart''' #Add new objects and connect them as shown below:</br>[[File:Step 6. Adding ticket control gates 5.png]] #Modify the properties of the [http://www.xjtek.com/anylogic/help/index.jsp?topic=/com.xj.anylogic.pedestrian_library/help/reference/PedGoTo.html PedGoTo] object. Now we want this block to move passengers not to subway trains but to our line located before the ticket control gates.</br>Set the following object properties:</br>[[File:Step 6. Adding ticket control gates 6.png]] #*Specify new destination for passengers. Choose <tt>lineBeforeGates</tt> as the '''Target (point, line)'''. #Configure [http://www.xjtek.com/anylogic/help/index.jsp?topic=/com.xj.anylogic.pedestrian_library/help/reference/PedServices.html PedServices] object. '''PedServices''' object represents one or multiple services and defines its default properties. Services defined by this object can be referenced by flowchart objects [http://www.xjtek.com/anylogic/help/index.jsp?topic=/com.xj.anylogic.pedestrian_library/help/reference/PedServices.html PedServices].</br>Set the following object properties:</br>[[File:Step 6. Adding ticket control gates 7.png]] #*'''Name''' this object <tt>gates</tt>. #*Specify the group containing lines representing services. Type <tt>gatesGroup</tt> in the '''Services (group of lines)''' field. #*Specify the group containing polylines representing queues to services. Type <tt>gatesQueuesGroup</tt> in the '''Queues (group of lines, polylines)''' field. #*Leave all other properties unchanged. You can see that the '''Delay''' time is uniformly distributed with minimum value of 2 seconds and maximum value of 3 seconds. Leave it since it is typical delay time for ticket control gates. #*Leave the '''Service type''': ''Delay and pass through''. There are two types of services in Pedestrian Library. ''Delay and pass through'' service is defined by a line, along which pedestrians should move. Pedestrian services at beginning point of the line and then moves to ending point before leaving service. We use it since we want passengers to pass through service lines representing ticket control gates. Another type of ''service'' (''Delay'') is also defined by line, which pedestrians should step on for service delay time. #Configure [http://www.xjtek.com/anylogic/help/index.jsp?topic=/com.xj.anylogic.pedestrian_library/help/reference/PedService.html PedService] object. '''PedService''' object is added into flowchart to model how pedestrian flow passes through a service defined by [http://www.xjtek.com/anylogic/help/index.jsp?topic=/com.xj.anylogic.pedestrian_library/help/reference/PedService.html PedService] object.</br>Set the following object properties:</br>[[File:Step 6. Adding ticket control gates 8.png]] #*Specify the '''PedServices''' object defining the service pedestrians will pass through. Type gates (the name of our '''PedServices''' object) in the '''Service (PedServices)''' field.
Now you can run the model and observe its behavior. You can see that now passengers pass through ticket control gates and sometimes queues are generated.
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Simulation with AnyLogic/Pedestrian Simulation/Step 7. Changing passenger arrival rate interactively

revision.comment: +category
revision.text:
==Step 7. Changing Passenger Arrival Rate Interactively==
In the current model the passenger arrival rate is fixed. However, AnyLogic provides a set of controls enabling changing the model parameters at the model runtime.
Now we will introduce how you can vary parameters of Pedestrian Library objects dynamically. We want to interactively change the passenger arrival rate to assure acceptable performance of service points with hypothetic load. We will introduce the corresponding control element in the presentation to change the rate interactively.
[[File:Step_1._Creating_a_new_model1.gif]] '''Add a slider to vary passenger arrival rate''' #Open the '''Controls''' stencil of the '''Palette''' and drag the '''Slider''' [[File:Step 7. Changing passenger arrival rate interactively 1.gif]] element from there into the graphical editor, e.g. to the right of the entrance layout:</br>[[File:Step 7. Changing passenger arrival rate interactively 2.png]] #Set the properties of the slider. We want to vary the passenger arrival rate from 0 to 5000 pedestrians per hour. Therefore, specify <tt>5000/hour()</tt> as slider’s '''Maximum value'''. We type <tt>5000/hour()</tt> here since the default model time unit in pedestrian models is day. And since we want to define our rate in peds per hour, we divide the value by the constant defining time value equal to one hour according to the current time unit setting. #Type <tt>1000/hour()</tt> as the slider's '''Default value'''. #Specify <tt>pedSource.set_rate(value);</tt> as the slider's '''Action'''. This code will modify the rate of our '''PedSource''' object each time the user will move the slider. <tt>value</tt> here is the local variable that stores the current value of the slider.</br>[[File:Step 7. Changing passenger arrival rate interactively 3.png]]
[[File:Step_1._Creating_a_new_model1.gif]] '''Add text labels for the slider''' #Add a title for the slider. Drag the '''Text''' [[File:Step 7. Changing passenger arrival rate interactively 4.gif]] element from the '''Presentation''' palette onto the diagram (above the slider). #Define the text to be displayed by this label in the '''Text''' property:</br>[[File:Step 7. Changing passenger arrival rate interactively 5.png]] #In the same way add two text labels displaying slider's minimum (''0'') and maximum (''5000'') values. Place them below the slider as shown in the figure below:</br>[[File:Step 7. Changing passenger arrival rate interactively 6.png]]
Run the model. Now you can change the passenger rate interactively with the slider. Therefore, you can find the maximal passenger arrival rate that can be served.
[[File:Step 7. Changing passenger arrival rate interactively 7.png]]
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Simulation with AnyLogic/Pedestrian Simulation/Step 8. Adding ticket windows

revision.comment: +category
revision.text:
==Step 8. Adding Ticket Windows==
Now we will expand our model by adding ticket windows.
[[File:Step_1._Creating_a_new_model1.gif]] '''Modify the model animation''' #Draw lines representing ticket windows as shown in the figure below.</br>[[File:Step 8. Adding ticket windows 1.png]] #Add these lines to a new group. Name the group <tt>windowsGroup</tt>. #Draw polylines representing queues to ticket windows as shown in the figure below.</br>[[File:Step 8. Adding ticket windows 2.png]] #The starting point of the polyline is important since it stands for the head of the queue. Place the first point of each polyline near the corresponding service line. #Add these polylines to a new group. Name the group <tt>windowsQueuesGroup</tt>. #Move <tt>lineBeforeGates</tt> a little bit down:</br>[[File:Step 8. Adding ticket windows 3.png]]
Now we will modify the model flowchart.
[[File:Step_1._Creating_a_new_model1.gif]] '''Modify the flowchart''' #Add new objects and connect them as shown below:</br>[[File:Step 8. Adding ticket windows 4.png]] #Configure [http://www.xjtek.com/anylogic/help/index.jsp?topic=/com.xj.anylogic.pedestrian_library/help/reference/PedServices.html PedServices] object. This object will define parameters of a service representing ticket windows. Services defined by this object can be referenced by flowchart objects [http://www.xjtek.com/anylogic/help/index.jsp?topic=/com.xj.anylogic.pedestrian_library/help/reference/PedServices.html PedServices].</br>Set the following object properties:</br>[[File:Step 8. Adding ticket windows 5.png]] #*'''Name''' this object <tt>windows</tt>. #*Specify the group containing lines representing services. Type <tt>windowsGroup</tt> in the '''Services (group of lines)''' field. #*Specify the group containing polylines representing queues to services. Type <tt>windowsQueuesGroup</tt> in the '''Queues (group of lines, polylines)''' field. #*Specify the service time. Type <tt>triangular(15*second(), 25*second(), 35*second())</tt> in the '''Delay''' field (you can use [http://www.xjtek.com/anylogic/help/index.jsp?topic=/com.xj.anylogic.help/html/wwanylogic/Using%20Intelli-sense.html code assist]). We assume that service time is triangularly distributed with minimum value of 15 seconds, average value of 25, and maximum value of 35 seconds. #*Change the '''Service type''' to ''Delay''. ''Delay'' service is defined by a line, which pedestrians should step on for service delay time. #Configure [http://www.xjtek.com/anylogic/help/index.jsp?topic=/com.xj.anylogic.pedestrian_library/help/reference/PedSelectOutput.html PedSelectOutput] object. We need it to route non-ticketed passengers to ticket windows while other ones – straight to the ticket control gates. '''PedSelectOutput''' object is a decision making block of Pedestrian Library. The pedestrian arrived at the '''PedSelectOutput''' object is forwarded along one of five output ports depending on ratios specified for these ports.</br>Set up the following object properties:</br>[[File:Step 8. Adding ticket windows 6.png]] #*Specify ratios for flows going to ticket control gates ('''Chance 1''') and to ticket windows ('''Chance 2''') correspondingly. In this flowchart we assume that the number of passengers that have already bought their tickets is actually significantly higher. #Configure just added [http://www.xjtek.com/anylogic/help/index.jsp?topic=/com.xj.anylogic.pedestrian_library/help/reference/PedService.html PedService] object. This flowchart object references to '''PedServices''' object defining a service representing subway ticket windows.</br>Set the following object properties:</br>[[File:Step 8. Adding ticket windows 7.png]] #*Specify the '''PedServices''' object defining the service pedestrians will pass through. Type <tt>windows</tt> (the name of our '''PedServices''' object) in the '''Service (PedServices)''' field.
Run the model. Note that now some passengers first go to the ticket windows to buy a ticket and only then pass through ticket control gates.
{{BookCat}}

==How to use the forum==
#Please add comment to the '''discussion''' part of this page - use the tab at the top of this page to see the discussion #Use the '''+''' tab at the top of the page to start a new topic. #Alternatively, use '''edit''' at the top of the page to add your own comments. To start a new topic use == to make a new heading and == to finish it i.e. ==heading== #To add your name and the time of your comment, use <nowiki>~~~~</nowiki> which wikimedia automatically converts to your name and the date. #If you are a registered user, you can '''watch''' the page and your '''watchlist''' will note the most recent addition to the forum. #It is polite to leave comments as they are once they have been posted. Tidying and editing posts to talkpages is discouraged.
[[User:Ewen|Ewen]] 07:10, 23 November 2007 (UTC)
{{BookCat}}

==Coded punctuation and assignment writing==
When I read the syllabus for BNA applied science, I can see that the learning outcomes are separated by semi-colons or commas. A fellow teacher told me that this was an Edexcel code for compulsory, advisory or voluntary. Does anyone know if this is so, or if there is any good, free information on the web on how to write good assignments to hit all the learning goals. .e.g. key words to be included etc.
19:08, 26 November 2007 [[User:Fossa|Fossa]] ([[User_talk:Fossa|Talk]] | [[Special:Contributions/Fossa|contribs]])
:No, I'm sure the punctuation is merely marking topics and sub-topics within a list.
:[http://www.edexcel.org.uk/VirtualContent/102614/NACD_in_Applied_Science_L3_TS.rtf Tutor support materials] - exemplar material for units 1, 4, 5, 29, 32 and 35. See p14 (and 15-19) for an assignment sheet that can be adapted.
:(I had to Google this sheet - am I alone in finding Edexcel's website to be impossible to navigate efficiently?).
:[http://www.edexcel.org.uk/VirtualContent/103974/Centre_briefing_NSS_2007_2008.pdf NSS Briefing 2007-08] - the final page is the cover sheet for units.
:PS Don't forget to sign comments with <nowiki>~~~~</nowiki>
:PPS Thanks for giving these pages a try!
:[[User:Ewen|Ewen]] 10:52, 27 November 2007 (UTC)
== Textbooks for BTEC students? ==
"I went to a meeting at our college on BTEC course and the lady mentioned that all students who are registered on BTEC course get a free book to help them during the course. I have not been able to get any answers from our exam officer."
Not my comment, but one that left me thinking: Where are these textbooks then? Any ideas anyone?
[[User:Ewen|Ewen]] 09:50, 28 November 2007 (UTC)
== Scenarios ==
Can we reject assignments if they do not meet the scenario?
I've had students submit work which was meant to be in the form of a 'Briefing for lawyers' and all they did was churn out the usual essay-style work. At first I thought 'Well, if they want to do the same style of assignment over and over then it's only themselves who get bored...'
However, it also affected the coverage of Key Skills as the students were essentially re-writing the assignment so that it covered the BTEC criteria but not the KS ones. Now I'm having to issue extra work to cover KS because they met the BTEC criteria, but not the scenario. So, how strongly should we / could we enforce compliance with the scenario?
[[User:Ewen|Ewen]] ([[User talk:Ewen|talk]]) 11:06, 1 June 2008 (UTC)
:Answer from Edexcel: If students meet the criteria, it doesn't matter if they ignore the scenario. [[User:Ewen|Ewen]] ([[User talk:Ewen|talk]]) 19:17, 5 June 2008 (UTC)
== Course structure ==
We run the full Diploma, the Award and the Certificate, which allows students to combine A-levels and the BTEC if they want. The Award can be done in one year (the first year of the Certificate) or over two years.
The Certificate is in our timetable blocks 'A' and 'C', and Award students have several options:
#Join the Cert Year 1 students in block A in year 1 of the Award, and then join the Cert Year 1 students in block C for Year 2 of the Award. #Join the Cert Year 1 students in block C in year 1 of the Award, and then join the Cert Year 1 students in block A for Year 2 of the Award. #Join the Cert Year 1 students in block A and C to complete the Award in one year.
I think a lot of centres enter all their students for the Award initially, in case a student doesn't progress to year 2 they can still claim 'success'.
What other models are out there?
[[User:Ewen|Ewen]] ([[User talk:Ewen|talk]]) 13:42, 1 June 2008 (UTC)

page.title: Geothermal Heating and Cooling/Air Loops and Basic HVAC

revision.comment: Rejected the last text change (by [[Special:Contributions/168.91.255.100|168.91.255.100]]) and restored revision 1600283 by Graeme E. Smith
revision.text:
Air Loops and Basic HVAC

It is important to note that what a Ground Source Heat Pump does, is affect the temperature of the air within a building. All the other effects are really the consequences of attempting to control the heat of the air within the building. In order to do this, the heat pump has to have some method of affecting the temperature of the air. We call this part of the system the Air Loop because while it is part of the refrigeration system, it is the side that directly affects air temperature. There are usually two types of heat that can be produced in the Air Loop, Direct Forced Air, where a refrigeration Loop actually heats and cools the air directly, and Radiant heat where the refrigeration loop heats and cools water, which then directly heats and cools the floor, radiating heat or coolness across the expanse of the floor, and thus heating or cooling the air indirectly. Radiant heat is thought to be the more efficient of the two, but people are more likely to have forced air in floors above the basement. There is one aspect of Ground Source Heat Pump Air Loops that practically eliminates the Option of retrofitting homes that already have forced air systems, and that is the prohibitive cost of re-plumbing the Air Pipes, that connect the furnace to the registers, to incorporate 15% larger pipes, so as to allow for greater air movement, to accommodate the lower heat output of a heat pump with regards to the heat output of an open flame. This does not affect the efficiency but does affect the renovation cost especially if the basement has been developed, building the HVAC system into the structure and requiring a tear down of the structure to accommodate the larger pipes. Retrofitting in a Forced Air Heat Pump system, requires gutting and re-framing the house to accommodate larger pipes. A combination system might work better as a retrofit where you do radiant heating in the basement, and thus have only to condition the heated air to keep it hot. In such a case the 15% increase in size of the HVAC pipes might be overcome with the heated basement, but no way to calculate this difference has been suggested in my existing manuals. {{BookCat}}

For more information contact:
Cassandra Zegarski
Wilkes University Ed.D Student
cassandra.zegarski@wilkes.edu

page.title: Talk:Blender 3D: Noob to Pro/Know What You're Doing

revision.text:
While this page is useful it uses terms, particularly in the section on organization, which are not explained within the book until much later. This could irritate/confuse potential readers who are new to 3D. Perhaps move to a later part of the book or remove technical details (it is far easier to understand "Always name everything in a meaningful way.") ——————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————
There is too much information for a Noob to swim through and much of it in not educational. I'd like to see less text that is more direct, moving the reader along since this isn't even a tutorial, but a primer. I made major changes to this page today. I hope they are kept.

revision.text:
== Welcome message ==
Hello, and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]!
Here are some tips to [[Help|help]] you get started: * To learn the wiki-markup-language syntax, see [[Help:Editing]]. * Make sure to sign your posts and comments with four tildes, like this: ~~~~ **There is a box at the top of the edit window (if javascript is enabled on your browser) that will insert it too (looks like part of a signature). This will let others know who left it, and make it easy to reply back to you. * Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * You can tell the community something about yourself in your userpage. ** You can get to this page by clicking the tab at the top of the page labeled with your registered username. * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. ([[WB:WIW|What is Wikibooks]]). * If you are a '''Wikipedian''', see [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikipedians]] for a primer on how things work here (it's a little different). ** If you want to base your work here on materials from Wikipedia, please use [[WB:RFI]]. * If you're an '''instructor''' and plan on using Wikibooks for a class project, see [[Wikibooks:Guidelines for class projects]] * Please say hello at the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]] with any questions or ideas. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Help us by participating in policy and guideline creation. ** Please take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] before starting a new book. * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun!
You will find more resources in [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you want to ask a question, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]], [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]] or [[User_talk:Panic2k4|ask me personally on my talk page]]. For site news, see the [[WB:BB|Bulletin board]]. It might be a good idea to add that page to your "[[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]]" so that you can see when any new information is posted there. You can do that by clicking the tab labeled "watch" at the top of the page.
Good luck! --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 20:13, 3 August 2009 (UTC)

== Talkback ==
{{tb|DroEsperanto}}

{{LinguisticsTOC}}
'''Descriptivism''' - Observation of how language is used. This is generally the method used in linguistics. (Cf. '''prescriptivism''')
'''Morpheme''' - An individual unit of meaning in a word. For example, the word ''uninterested'' may be analyzed as consisting of three morphemes: ''un-'', ''interest'', and ''-ed''. (Morphemes are sometimes also considered to contain units which have no basic phonological representation, see ''reduplication'', ''truncation'').
'''Morphology''' - The study of how units of meaning are combined together to create words. The basic units of reference in morphology are ''morphemes''.
'''Phone''' - A unit of sound or a gesture used to produce one in a language. Note that different phones may have the same underlying representation in a language (see ''phoneme'').
'''Phoneme''' - A class of phones which contrast with other phonemes in a language. For instance, in English the phoneme /t/ is realized as a plosive at the beginning of a word (e.g. ''term'') but as a flap between vowels in most positions (e.g. ''butter''), while in other languages these two sounds are different phonemes.
'''Phonetics''' - The study of the different types of sounds used in human language and how they are produced and perceived. The basic units of representation in phonetics are ''phones''.
'''Phonology''' - The study of how languages group phones together and use them to encode meaning. The basic units of representation in phonology are ''phonemes''.
'''Prescriptivism''' - Ruling on how language should used. This is common in language instruction but is generally irrelevant to linguistics. (Cf. '''descriptivism''')
'''Register''' - a different type of speech adopted by a language-user depending on context
'''Rounding''' - "puckering" of the lips while producing a phone, most commonly a vowel

==Changing chord diagrams==
Hello. I'm changing the chord diagrams. If you object please revert to previous diagrams. I'm going to remove the editorial comment about the Hendrix chord. Shouldn't it be left on this talk page or on the users talk page. I've added the scale manual and the technical exercises.
"EDIT: THE CHORD NAME ABOVE IS INCORRECT. It is simply a 7/#9 chord. It has a major third in it, so is NOT a minor chord. The #9 is the same note (sonically) as the minor third, so if it were a minor chord, you could not have a #9. If the author is trying to say that it is a flatted 7th (as opposed to a natural 7th) in the chord spelling, then he should write "Dominant 7/#9". Writing "Minor 7th" means it's a minor chord w/ a dominant 7th."
The above is the comment I'm removing. I'm correcting the chord symbol.
Here is the second comment I'm removing. Like the other comment it is correct. I'm changing the chord symbol.
EDIT: ALSO INCORRECT! If it is a 7th chord, you do NOT write "add 9". Just write: B7/9 or B7/9/13. Use "add 9" if you intend the player to play a triad, with no 7th, but adding the 9th on top, i.e. "B add 9". Again, as above, this is not a "minor 7th" chord, but a "dominant 7th" chord.
Thanks --[[User:Sluffs|Sluffs]] ([[User talk:Sluffs|talk]]) 21:34, 3 August 2009 (UTC)

revision.comment: Schema document comments are in error
revision.text:
The comments in the schema document appear to be wrong. XSD patterns must match the entire literal value; it is as if they had implicit start-of-string and end-of-string anchors at the beginning and end of the pattern. So the zip type is in fact correct. The zip2 type, by contrast, does not match zip codes but requires a leading caret and a trailing dollar sign.
Does XForms prescribe a different pattern syntax?
--C. M. Sperberg-McQueen, Black Mesa Technologies

{{recipe}} [[Category:Chicken recipes]] [[Category:Fried recipes]]
== Ingredients == * 24 chicken wings, tip removed, cut in half at the joint * 10 tbs [[Cookbook:Kansas City Barbecue Sauce|barbecue sauce]] * 1/2 tsp hickory-flavored liquid smoke * 2 1/2 quarts peanut or canola oil * 3 tbs [[Cookbook:Hickory BBQ Rub|hickory-flavored seasoning]]
== Procedure == #Combine sauce and smoke. Set aside. #Season chicken evenly with seasoning. Set aside. #Heat oil to 350 degrees F. Add chicken, and working in batches, cook 10-12 minutes or golden brown, crisp, and cooked through to 165°F. Drain on a cooling rack. #Once all chicken has been fried, toss with sauce mixture. Serve warm with blue cheese dressing.

{{recipe}} [[Category:Beef recipes]] [[Category:French recipes]] [[Category:Pepper recipes]]
== Ingredients == * 4 (6-8 ounce) beef tenderloin steaks, 1 inch thick * 2 tbs black peppercorns, cracked * Salt * 1/3 cup cognac * 1 cup heavy cream * 1/4 cup unsalted butter, divided * 2 tsp olive oil
== Procedure == #Sprinkle steaks on both sides liberally with kosher salt. Press peppercorns into both sides of each steak. Let sit 30 minutes or until room temperature. #Melt 1 tbs butter with oil in a large '''stainless steel''' skillet over medium high heat. Add steaks and cook 5 minutes per side for medium rare, 6 for medium, and 7 for well done. Remove from pan and keep warm. #Raise heat in pan to high. Turn off the heat, then deglaze pan with cognac. Carefully ignite with a firestick, then swirl the pan until flames die. #Put heat to medium and whisk continuously to remove fond. Bring to a boil and cook until liquid has reduced by 1/2. #Whisk in cream. Bring to a boil and cook until liquid has reduced to 1/3 cup. #Slowly whisk in butter, 1 tbs at a time. Spoon sauce over steaks and serve warm.
== Notes ==
Don't even think about using a nonstick pan. Repeat after me, "You can't build a pan sauce in a nonstick skillet". Good.
If you don't want to ignite the cognac, you do not have to. I just put it in because it makes a performance that makes people stare at you with amazement.
== Warnings ==
If you do choose to ignite, remember to keep a lid, in case things get out of hand, and a fire extinguisher, in case something bad happens and you need it.

Mike Pevear
Wilkes University Ed.D student
Michael.Pevear@wilkes.edu

----

To contact the author:

Melanie Wiscount

Wilkes University Ed.D. educational technology student

melanie.wiscount@wilkes.edu

Assistive Technology Research Project

Wilkes University

July 2009

revision.text: == Category:New Books == {{closed|Since the original nominator has changed their opinion of the nominated item to keep and everyone else agrees to keep it, this is closed as [[File:Symbol keep vote.svg|15px]] '''Keep'''. -- [[User:Adrignola|Adrignola]] [[User talk:Adrignola|talk]] [[Special:Contributions/Adrignola|contribs]] 00:59, 4 August 2009 (UTC)}} [[:Category:New Books]] I think this category should be deleted because it is not used. It is not a dynamic list and has only 18 pages. [[User:Arlen22|Arlen22]] ([[User talk:Arlen22|talk]]) 21:52, 31 July 2009 (UTC) :[[File:Symbol keep vote.svg|15px]] '''Keep'''. It is used by {{tlx|new book}} to generate the dynamic list seen by including {{tlx|new}}. --[[User:Darklama|dark]][[User_talk:Darklama|lama]] 22:07, 31 July 2009 (UTC) :Yes I know that, but the category is not used and further more the template {{tlx|new}} only shows the list of books in the category. It would be better to delete the Category and make a true list of newly created books. Or maybe I am way off. When are books added to this category? If as soon as they are made, then I am right on. But if books are added when they are complete then this is a good category. [[User:Arlen22|Arlen22]] ([[User talk:Arlen22|talk]]) 23:14, 31 July 2009 (UTC) :: How can you say the category is not used, if you know that? {{tlx|new}} uses the category for its list. Books are added to the list by using {{tlx|new book}}. {{tlx|new book}} is added to new books when they are first created and usually kept on a page for about 2 weeks. Its no different from how {{tlx|CategoryList}} is used on your newly created library page. Should we delete all those categories too than? Before using a dynamic list to generate new books it was done so manually. There is no advantage to deleting this category. There is no other way to see a list of newly created books. --[[User:Darklama|dark]][[User_talk:Darklama|lama]] 00:06, 1 August 2009 (UTC) :::Ok so they are used as soon as the book is made, even if the book isn't done yet. In that case it could be a dynamic list in order to minimize maintanance. This one we still have to add books to the category. That is why I think we should delete the category. If it isn't possible to make a list like that then I say {{keep}}. —The preceding [[w:Wikipedia:Sign your posts on talk pages|unsigned]] comment was added by [[User:Arlen22|Arlen22]] ([[User talk:Arlen22|talk]] • [[Special:Contributions/Arlen22|contribs]]) 12:16, 1 August 2009. ::::Yes, the meaning is "newly created book". (There is, BTW, no such thing as a book being "done" here; unless a book is deleted, further changes are always possible.) --[[User:Pi zero|Pi zero]] ([[User talk:Pi zero|talk]]) 15:54, 1 August 2009 (UTC) {{new}} :[[File:Symbol keep vote.svg|15px]] '''Keep'''. I agree with darklama, it is good to keep a list of newly created books. I agree there are difficulties, I think lots of times books don't get added to it, and it seems to me books stay in there longer then two weeks. But overall I think it is helpful. [[User:Thenub314|Thenub314]] ([[User talk:Thenub314|talk]]) 07:47, 1 August 2009 (UTC) :[[File:Symbol keep vote.svg|15px]] '''Keep''' --[[User:Pi zero|Pi zero]] ([[User talk:Pi zero|talk]]) 15:54, 1 August 2009 (UTC) {{end closed}}

page.title: Wikibooks:Requests for deletion/2 Button Mens Suits

revision.comment: moved [[Wikibooks:Votes for deletion/2 Button Mens Suits]] to [[Wikibooks:Requests for deletion/2 Button Mens Suits]]: Per [[Wikibooks_talk:Votes_for_deletion#Page_rename_proposal]]
revision.text:
<noinclude>== 2 Button Mens Suits ==</noinclude> {{closed|Closed as [[File:Symbol delete vote.svg|15px]] '''speedy delete'''. This page is a copy and paste of [http://www.wikihow.com/Pick-a-Collar-for-a-Men%27s-Dress-Shirt the page at wikiHow]. That site's licensing is [http://www.wikihow.com/wikiHow:Creative-Commons CC-BY-NC-SA] which prohibits noncommercial uses. As such, it is an unacceptable license for copying content into Wikibooks under. Nothing further to discuss. -- [[User:Adrignola|Adrignola]] <sup>[[User talk:Adrignola|talk]] [[Special:Contributions/Adrignola|contribs]]</sup> 01:34, 4 August 2009 (UTC)}} This page was tagged as a speedy by [[User:Geoff Plourde|Geoff Plourde]] (3 August 2009). I think that there is some content that shouldn't be simply deleted and that the stub is of value and too recent (12 June 2009) to be merely deleted, so I changed the speedy request for a VFD. --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 19:33, 3 August 2009 (UTC)
:[[File:Symbol keep vote.svg|15px]] '''Keep''' I have toned down the links and provided 2 other alternatives (random selections from a search on the topic) so the spam issue is partially addressed. : In any case the page is too recent and does have content that shouldn't be lost. I feel again that talking with the page creator and educating him would be more productive (even if there is some suspicions of bad faith) that doesn't affect the content nor the value of the subject the page covers. The creator was welcomed and an attempt to request more input was made but it seems not replied to. : I also urge that someone that can would check the page history and if the 3 contributors that attempted to flood the page with the same link are identical or from the same range a block of the most recent ones should be considered as the action demonstrates bad faith in a coordinated way. : Finally, the page should be renamed (haven't searched for other works that could use the content) or could be merged. : In any case a good catch by [[User:Geoff Plourde|Geoff Plourde]]... --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 19:42, 3 August 2009 (UTC) :{{comment}} I don't care either way, but... Wikibooks does not seem the appropriate place to stash a one page handout on men's suits. Now, if someone wanted to write a book on suits/clothing, that's another matter. Maybe we should move this to userspace? [[User:Geoff Plourde|Geoff Plourde]] ([[User talk:Geoff Plourde|talk]]) 20:10, 3 August 2009 (UTC) ::{{comment}} Only the owner of the user space can make that decission. In any case we do support stubs on this project no one is expected to commit to the full creation of a work. If some content is usable we should strive to keep it, see the above discussion about [[English Grammar 2]]. ::Since the VFD was not initiated only due to the speedy (if so I would have talked to you directly) but due to the multiple accounts that engaged on the action you detected. Have you checked that the content is proper? (I haven't examined if it was copied form somewhere else, just to justify the addition of the links...) --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 20:45, 3 August 2009 (UTC) :::See [http://www.wikihow.com/Pick-a-Collar-for-a-Men%27s-Dress-Shirt this] [[User:Geoff Plourde|Geoff Plourde]] ([[User talk:Geoff Plourde|talk]]) 01:21, 4 August 2009 (UTC) {{end closed}}

revision.comment: /* Domains */
revision.text:
The [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CompTIA CompTIA] Security+ certification designates knowledgeable professionals in the field of security, one of the fastest-growing fields in IT. Security threats are increasing in number and severity, and the gap between the need for security professionals and qualified IT personnel is the largest of any IT specialty, according to a 2008 CompTIA study. Even in a troubled economy, most businesses plan to maintain or increase their investment in security.
CompTIA Security+ is an international, vendor-neutral certification that proves competency in system security, network infrastructure, access control and organizational security. Major organizations that employ CompTIA Security+ certified staff include Booz Allen Hamilton, Hewlett-Packard, IBM, Motorola, Symantec, Telstra, Hitachi, Ricoh, Lockheed Martin, Unisys, Hilton Hotels Corp., General Mills, the U.S. Navy, Army, Air Force and Marines.
Although not a prerequisite, it is recommended that CompTIA Security+ candidates have at least two years of technical networking experience, with an emphasis on security. The CompTIA Network+ certification is also recommended.
== Domains == # [[/Network Security/]] # [[/Compliance and Operational Security/]] # [[/Threats and Vulnerabilities/]] # [[/Application, Data and Host Security/]] # [[/Access Control and Identity Management/]] # [[/Cryptography/]]
== Test Details == Number of questions: 100
Length of test: 90 minutes
Passing score: 750 on a scale of 100-900
Recommended experience: CompTIA Network+ certification and two years of technical networking experience, with an emphasis on security.
Languages: English, Spanish, German, Japanese, Chinese
Exam codes: SY0-301, JK0-015
== See Also == * [[A+ Certification]] * [[Network Plus Certification]]
=== External links === * [http://www.comptia.org/certifications/listed/security.aspx/ Official CompTIA Security+ Certification Site] * [http://www.professormesser.com/free-comptia-security-training/security-plus-videos/ Professor Messer's CompTIA SY0-301 Security+ Training - free videos] * [http://www.securitypluscertification.net/comptia-security-plus-exam-study-guide/ CompTIA Security+ Certification Study Guide]
{{Subjects|IT certifications}}

revision.comment: moved [[Wikibooks:Votes for deletion/Category:Gardening pages]] to [[Wikibooks:Requests for deletion/Category:Gardening pages]]: Per [[Wikibooks_talk:Votes_for_deletion#Page_rename_proposal]]
revision.text: == [[:Category:Gardening pages]] == {{closed|Closed as [[File:Symbol delete vote.svg|15px]] '''Delete'''. I've left this up here for months and no objections to deletion have been registered here or on the below referenced talk page. Wikibooks is not Wikisource and the material on these pages is at [[s:Manual of Gardening|Manual of Gardening]] and [[s:Home Vegetable Gardening|Home Vegetable Gardening]] should anyone have need of it. Anything missing from those texts is being pulled from Project Gutenberg and not here. Finally, if SB Johnny, as a major contributor to [[Horticulture]], isn't interested in them, then I feel safe deleting them. -- [[User:Adrignola|Adrignola]] [[User talk:Adrignola|talk]] [[Special:Contributions/Adrignola|contribs]] 03:08, 4 August 2009 (UTC)}} The contents of this category have just been sitting there and it seems like, from the contents of [[Wikibooks talk:Pages to be transwikied/Gardening]], that they are abandoned and other source material is being used to populate Wikisource, rather than the pages in the above category. At least that's the way I interpret it. [[Talk:Gardening]] also indicates that a new book would be started ([[Horticulture]]) that would not use the pages in this category. So they are no longer being transwikied and they have been dismissed as not acceptable for a merge. I humbly propose they be deleted rather than sit in limbo. -- [[User:Adrignola|Adrignola]] [[User talk:Adrignola|talk]] [[Special:Contributions/Adrignola|contribs]] 16:13, 17 May 2009 (UTC) * '''Delete'''. ''If'' the pages aren't useful for merger into other places like [[Horticulture]] they probably should be deleted. --'''Whiteknight''' ([[User:Whiteknight|Page]]) ([[User talk:Whiteknight|Talk]]) 16:25, 17 May 2009 (UTC) * '''Delete'''. These pages has been in limbo a long time. Wikisource has had plenty of time to transwiki them if they were going to use them. The Horticulture book has also had plenty of time to adopt them if they were going to be used. The Gardening pages are part of a book that became public domain due to its age and that is why it was suppose to have been transfered to Wikisource to begin with from what I understand. --[[User:Darklama|dark]][[User_talk:Darklama|lama]] 11:43, 18 May 2009 (UTC) * '''Comment''' - most of the information in the old gardening book is quite out of date. It's interesting as a historical text, but not particularly useful as a textbook for modern gardening techniques. --[[User:SB_Johnny|'''SB_Johnny''']] [[User_talk:SB_Johnny|talk]] 14:08, 3 June 2009 (UTC) * '''Get Rid Of It''' Anywhere, just not here [[User:Geoff Plourde|Geoff Plourde]] ([[User talk:Geoff Plourde|talk]]) 17:51, 3 August 2009 (UTC) {{end closed}}

revision.comment: Created page with 'Zeus is associated with capricorn and Hera with libra? You might want to double check that because I thoroughly believe that to be untrue. If anything it is the opposite. But in ...'
revision.text: Zeus is associated with capricorn and Hera with libra? You might want to double check that because I thoroughly believe that to be untrue. If anything it is the opposite. But in reality, Hera is associated with Capricorn and Saturn and Zeus is associated with Aries or even Libra. Zeus in my mind is positively an Aries because of the derivation of the word zeus which is yeu or youth. Aries is the most youthful of all the signs! I don't really have a reason why Hera takes after Kronos other than that I am exactly like Hera and I am a Capricorn. I just see the saturn in her nature. But I would just do a little more research into this idea to make sure that what makes it to the page is solid fact.

revision.text:
{{LinguisticsTOC}} ==The International Phonetic Alphabet== The '''International Phonetic Alphabet''' is a system of phonetic notation which provides a standardized system of representing the sounds of spoken languages. It may be represented visually using charts, which are given here for reference: ===Consonants=== Pulmonic consonants are those made by obstructing the glottis (the space between the vocal cords) or oral cavity (the mouth) and either simultaneously or subsequently letting out air from the lungs. Where symbols appear in pairs, the one to the right represents a voiced consonant. Shaded areas denote articulations judged as impossible. {| class="wikitable" border="1" style="text-align: center;" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="3" ! colspan=13 | [[media:IPA consonants 2005.png|View this table as an image.]] |- ! ! Bilabial ! Labiodental ! Dental ! Alveolar ! Postalveolar ! Retroflex ! Palatal ! Velar ! Uvular ! Pharyngeal ! Epiglottal ! Glottal |- ! Plosive | p b | | colspan="3" | t d | {{IPA|ʈ ɖ}} | {{IPA|c ɟ}} | k g | {{IPA|q ɢ}} | | {{IPA|ʡ}} | {{IPA|ʔ}} |- ! Nasal | m | {{IPA| ɱ}} | colspan="3" | n | {{IPA|ɳ}} | {{IPA|ɲ}} | ŋ | {{IPA|ɴ}} | bgcolor="aaaaaa" | | bgcolor="aaaaaa" | | bgcolor="aaaaaa" | |- ! Trill | {{IPA|ʙ}} | | colspan="3" | r | | bgcolor="aaaaaa" | | | {{IPA|ʀ}} | | | bgcolor="aaaaaa" | |- ! Tap or Flap | | | colspan="3" | {{IPA|ɾ}} | {{IPA|ɽ}} | bgcolor="aaaaaa" | | | | | | bgcolor="aaaaaa" | |- ! Fricative | {{IPA|ɸ β}} | f v | θ ð | s z | {{IPA|ʃ ʒ}} | {{IPA|ʂ ʐ}} | {{IPA|ç ʝ}} | {{IPA|x ɣ}} | {{IPA|χ ʁ}} | {{IPA|ħ ʕ}} | {{IPA|ʜ ʢ}} | {{IPA|h ɦ}} |- ! Lateral fricative | bgcolor="aaaaaa" | | bgcolor="aaaaaa" | | colspan="3" | {{IPA|ɬ ɮ}} | | | | | bgcolor="aaaaaa" | | bgcolor="aaaaaa" | | bgcolor="aaaaaa" | |- ! Approximant | | {{IPA|ʋ}} | colspan="3" | {{IPA|ɹ}} | {{IPA|ɻ}} | j | {{IPA|ɰ}} | | | {{IPA|ʢ}} | bgcolor="aaaaaa" | |- ! Lateral approximant | bgcolor="aaaaaa" | | bgcolor="aaaaaa" | | colspan="3" | l | {{IPA|ɭ}} | {{IPA|ʎ}} | {{IPA|ʟ}} | | bgcolor="aaaaaa" | | bgcolor="aaaaaa" | | bgcolor="aaaaaa" | |} Coarticulated consonants are sounds that involve two simultaneous places of articulation (are pronounced using two parts of the vocal tract). In English, the [w] in "went" is a coarticulated consonant, because it is pronounced by rounding the lips and raising the back of the tongue. Other languages, such as French and Swedish, have different coarticulated consonants. {| class="IPA wikitable" ! colspan=2 | [[media:IPA co-articulated 2005.png|View this table as an image]] |- | style="text-align:center; font-size:larger; width:2em;" | ʍ | Voiceless labialized velar approximant |- | style="text-align:center; font-size:larger;" | w | Voiced labialized velar approximant |- | style="text-align:center; font-size:larger;" | ɥ | Voiced labialized palatal approximant |- | style="text-align:center; font-size:larger;" | ɕ | Voiceless palatalized postalveolar (alveolo-palatal) fricative |- | style="text-align:center; font-size:larger;" | ʑ | Voiced palatalized postalveolar (alveolo-palatal) fricative |- | style="text-align:center; font-size:larger;" | ɧ | Voiceless "palatal-velar" fricative |} Non-pulmonic consonants are sounds whose airflow is not dependent on the lungs. These include clicks (found in the Khoisan languages of Africa), implosives (found in languages such as Swahili) and ejectives (found in many Amerindian and Caucasian languages). {| class="IPA wikitable" ! colspan=6 | [[media:IPA non-pulmonic 2005.png|View this table as an image]] |- valign=top ! colspan="2" | Clicks ! colspan="2" | Implosives ! colspan="2" | Ejectives |- valign=top | style="text-align:center; font-size:larger; width:2em;" | {{IPA|ʘ}} | Bilabial | style="text-align:center; font-size:larger; width:2em;" | {{IPA|ɓ}} | Bilabial | style="text-align:center; font-size:larger; width:2em;" | {{IPA|ʼ}} | ''For example:'' |- valign=top | style="text-align:center; font-size:larger;" | {{IPA|ǀ}} | Laminal alveolar ("dental") | style="text-align:center; font-size:larger;" | {{IPA|ɗ}} | Alveolar | style="text-align:center; font-size:larger;" | {{IPA|pʼ}} | Bilabial |- valign=top | style="text-align:center; font-size:larger;" | {{IPA|ǃ}} | Apical (post-) alveolar ("retroflex") | style="text-align:center; font-size:larger;" | {{IPA|ʄ}} | Palatal | style="text-align:center; font-size:larger;" | {{IPA|tʼ}} | Alveolar |- valign=top | style="text-align:center; font-size:larger;" | {{IPA|ǂ}} | Laminal postalveolar ("palatal") | style="text-align:center; font-size:larger;" | {{IPA|ɠ}} | Velar | style="text-align:center; font-size:larger;" | {{IPA|kʼ}} | Velar |- valign=top | style="text-align:center; font-size:larger;" | {{IPA|ǁ}} | Lateral coronal ("lateral") | style="text-align:center; font-size:larger;" | {{IPA|ʛ}} | Uvular | style="text-align:center; font-size:larger;" | {{IPA|sʼ}} | Alveolar fricative |} ===Vowels=== Below is a chart depicting the vowels of the IPA. The IPA maps the vowels according to the position of the tongue. In places where vowels are paired, the right represents a rounded vowel (in which the lips are rounded) while the left is its unrounded counterpart. {| class="IPA" cellspacing="0px" cellpadding=0 style="text-align:center; background:transparent;" |+ [[media:IPA vowel chart 2005.png|View the vowel chart as an image]] |- style="text-align:center; font-size:smaller;" | | style="width: 60px;" | '''Front''' | style="width: 60px; word-spacing: -.3em;" | '''Near- front''' | style="width: 60px;" | '''Central''' | style="width: 60px;word-spacing: -.3em;" | '''Near- back''' | style="width: 60px;" | '''Back''' |- | style="height: 30px; font-size: smaller; text-align: right;" | '''Close''' | style="height: 210px;" colspan=5 rowspan=7 |
[[Image:Blank vowel trapezoid.svg|300px]]

revision.comment: [[:commons:COM:FR|File renamed]]: [[File:Jimmie.jpg]] → [[File:Jimmie Rodgers.jpg]] more clear description
revision.text:
==Introduction== [[File:Appalachian Region of US.png|thumb|375px|right|The Appalachian Region of the US]] Country music is a uniquely american genre of music that can trace its roots back to earlier european folk songs that the arriving immigrants brought with them. It developed in the Appalachians and surrounding states; changing the forms and sounds of the earlier folk songs until the music reflected the conditions that these early american settlers experienced. The music itself has never stopped absorbing elements from other genres such as blues, ragtime, jazz, rock and contemporary folk. It is this vitality that has kept country music at the heart of american culture.
===History===
Country music, like most early folk music, was passed down orally from generation to generation; with each adding to the existing tradition. The guitar, being cheap and portable, was ideal for country musicians and from the earliest days has been associated with the music.
It was the invention of the phonograph and radio that led to the creation of the first national country stars The Carter Family. The Carter Family also sung gospel, Victorian ballads and vaudeville songs. The guitar solo in their song "Wildwood Flower" is an early example of characteristics that are still to be found in country lead breaks.
Country guitarists also absorbed elements from the blues and slide guitar started to be featured shortly after the success of the Carter Family. Jimmie Rodgers (1897-1933) was the first solo star of country music and his guitar style is a mixture of country alternating bass and the blues form.
Country music took on some on the elements of the big band era of the 1930s. The growth of bigger bands that included instruments such as drums and saxophones led to the creation of Western Swing. Whereas the music of the Carter Family and Jimmie Rodgers had retained some of the earlier folk ballad qualities; Western Swing was primarily for dancing.
===Guitars===
Acoustic guitars have been a firm favourite for country musicians since the 1920s. The "open" resonating sound of these guitars suit the country and western chordal style. The Gibson L-5 was popular (the instrument played by Maybelle Carter) as were Martin guitars. It musn't be overlooked that Gibsons and Martins are professional marque guitars and that many players would have started on cheaper models by other manufacturers.
The Dobro Resonator guitar was also used from the 1930s onwards. Its unique timbre appealed to country guitarists and its volume allowed it to be heard amongst the expanding line-up of instruments.
Other instruments that are commonly used in country music are the fiddle and banjo.
==Exercise One==
This exercise uses these chords:
<gallery perrow=3> <font face="Courier New"> File:G major chord for guitar (open).png|'''G''' File:C major chord for guitar (open).png|'''C''' File:D major chord for guitar (open).png|'''D''' </font> </gallery>
This is an exercise for alternating the bass. It is recommended that this exercise be played without a plectrum. Use the thumb of your right hand to play the alternating bass notes. The right hand fingers must also form a "claw" and be placed on the three treble strings to start this exercise. The ring finger of the right hand always takes the highest note. After playing the bass note with your thumb; slightly lift your right hand fingers to sound the treble strings. Don't pluck or pull away your right hand. A slight lift of your right hand index, middle and ring finger is enough to sound the chord and then return your hand back for the next lift. Practice this exercise slowly for accuracy especially placing the claw correctly and ensuring that after the lift the fingers are only millimeters away and ready to be placed again. There should be no movement of the forearm or wrist; all the work is done by the fingers. The left hand holds down the chords as shown above. Most tab exercises will have chord diagrams that show the chords to be used.
[[File:Country style alternating bass exercise 01.png|thumb|left|800px|Country style alternating bass in G major]] <br style="clear:both" /> ==Essential Country Guitarists and Recordings== [[File:Jimmie Rodgers.jpg|thumb|right|The Country and Western performer Jimmie Rodgers]] * The Carter Family - a long career has led to many Carter Family recordings but the early recordings between 1927 and 1941 on the Victor label are considered to be the best of the original Carter family line-up. Some of the Carter Family's radio performances are in the public domain and can be found on-line for listening or download.
* Jimmie Rodgers - his first hit record was "Blue Yodel (T for Texas)". The first country solo artist to achieve national fame in the US.
* Hank Williams - the writer of "Your Cheating Heart" and "Hey, Good Lookin"
* Willie Nelson - the country performer and song-writer who wrote "Crazy" (Patsy Cline).
* Chet Atkins - one of the architects of the "Nashville" sound. A guitarist of wide skills who has performed on the records of Elvis Presely and the Everley Brothers; as well as issuing his own solo releases and duos with the guitarist Jimmy Reed.
* Leon McAuliff - one of the great Western Swing steel guitarists. Played with Bob Wills' Texas Playboys.
'''
{{Guitar}} [[Category:Guitar]]

revision.text:
Welcome to the '''Wikibooks Driving Guide'''. This book covers the basics of driving, including basic driver safety, advanced driving techniques, and relevant vehicle maintenance topics. It is a work in progress; refer to chapter 10 for ways in which you may help improve it.
== Content == The '''Wikibooks Driving Guide''' contains content suitable for both new and experienced drivers; as well as for mentors to new drivers, such as parents with teenagers reaching the driving age. All content in the '''Wikibooks Driving Guide''' is suitable for all classes of drivers.
Within, you will find several topics including vehicle safety, technique, and maintenance across a wide range of driving conditions including personal, professional, and precision or "racing" conditions. When executed correctly and with proper judgment, all techniques are useful in all driving conditions. Some conditions, such as precision driving for motorsports, will require the use of specialized techniques more than others; other condition, such as personal "street" driving, will demand more conservative and generalized driving technique but occasionally benefit from advanced specialized techniques to avoid or neutralize hazardous conditions.
The content covered within serves only to raise driver awareness in the field of driving. Specialized, hands-on driver's education courses for a variety of driving styles exist. For example, specific Advanced Driver's Education courses cover vehicle dynamics and handling techniques as they apply to unpredictable hazardous situations in every-day driving conditions. Specialized autocrossing driver's education courses cover vehicle dynamics and handling techniques under extreme road conditions and at maximized speeds.
{{BookCat}}

revision.text:
The '''present subjunctive''' in Spanish is formed by adding the following endings to the stems of verbs: -ar: -e, -es, -e, -emos,- éis, -en -er/-ir: -a, -as, -a, -amos, -áis, -an
Verbs that are stem changing/ boot verbs in the present indicative will do the same in the present subjunctive. If a verb has an irregular yo form in the present indicative that is the base form for the present subjunctive; hence tener, tengo, becomes: tenga, tengas, tenga, etc., or oír, oigo, becomes: oiga, oigas, oiga, etc.
Verbs that end in –uir, like huir, which have a ‘y’ between stem and ending in the boot (all forms but nosotros and vosotros) in the present indicative function as yo irregulars: all six forms in the present subjunctive have the ‘y’: huya, huyas, huya, huyamos, huyáis, huyan.
For phonetic reasons there are various spell changes. The –car, -gar, -zar, -guar yo spell changes in the preterit occur in all six forms of the present subjunctive. Sacar: saque, saques, saque, etc. Llegar: llegue, llegues, llegue, etc. Lanzar: lance, lances, lance, etc. Averiguar: averigüe, averigües, averigüe, etc. Also yo spell changes from the present indicative will occur in all six forms in the present subjunctive for: -ger/gir, consonent+-zar, -guir. Escoger: escoja, escojas, escoja, etc. Vencer: venza, venzas, venza, etc. Seguir: siga, sigas, siga, etc.
-ir stem changing verbs will have a change in the nosotros and vosotros forms, with the ‘o’ in the stem becoming a ‘u’ or the ‘e’ becoming an ‘i’. Morir: muera, mueras, muera, muramos, muráis, mueran. Sentir: sienta, sientas, sienta, sintamos, sintáis, sientan.
There are six irregular verbs in the present subjunctive: Ser: sea, seas, sea, seamos, seáis, sean Ir: vaya, vayas, vaya, vayamos, vayáis, vayan Saber: sepa, sepas, sepa, sepamos, sepáis, sepan Haber: haya, hayas, haya, hayamos, hayáis, hayan Estar: esté, estés, esté, estemos, estéis, estén Dar: dé, des, dé, demos, deis, den
The '''imperfect subjunctive''' in Spanish is formed by adding the following endings to the third person plural of the preterit after removing the ‘-ron’ -ra, -ras, -ra, ’-ramos, -rais, -ran
Hence hablar, hablaron, becomes: hablara, hablaras, hablara, habláramos, hablarais, hablaran
Or vivir, vivieron, becomes: viviera, vivieras, viviera, viviéramos, vivierais, vivieran An alternative, less used, set of endings is also available: -se, -ses, -se, ’-semos, -seis, -sen
The '''future subjunctive''' (not commonly used but an accepted form), like the imperfect subjunctive, is formed using the third person plural of the preterit after removing the ‘-ron’. The endings are: -re, -res, -re, ’-remos, -reis, -ren
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Adventist Youth Honors Answer Book/Arts and Crafts/Macrame

revision.comment: clean up, typos fixed: sprial → spiral using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{honor_header|1|1975|Arts and Crafts|General Conference}} ==1. Give a brief history of the art of decorative knotting.== Macramé, the modern art of decorating with knots, is believed to have originated with 13th-century Arab weavers. These artisans knotted the excess thread and yarn along the edges of hand-loomed fabrics into decorative fringes on bath towels, shawls, and veils. The word macramé is derived from the Arabic migramah (مقرمة), believed to mean "striped towel", "ornamental fringe" or "embroidered veil." After the Moorish conquest, the art was taken to Spain, and then spread through Europe. It was first introduced into England by Kathleen Koons at the court of Queen Mary, the wife of William of Orange, in the late 17th century.
Sailors made macramé objects at sea, and sold and bartered them when they landed, thus spreading the art to places like China and the New World. Macramé remained a popular pastime with 19th- century British and American seamen, who called it square knotting after the knot they most preferred in making hammocks, bell fringes, and belts.
Macramé reached its zenith in the Victorian era. Sylvia's Book of Macramé Lace, a favorite at that time, urged its readers "to work rich trimmings for black and coloured costumes, both for home wear, garden parties, seaside ramblings, and balls- fairylike adornments for household and underlinens ..." Few Victorian homes went unadorned.
While the craze for macramé waned in later years, it is now popular again, for making wall hangings, articles of clothing, bedspreads, small jean shorts, tablecloths, draperies, plant hangers and other furnishings.
==2. What is a good macramé cord? == Cotton seine twine is recommended for the beginner because with this material, the patterns are easier to see and the knots are easy to tighten.
==3. Know three kinds of cords that are good and why they are good.== Common materials used in macramé include cotton twine, hemp, leather or yarn.
;Cotton twine: Soft, flexible, easy to obtain, cheap ;Hemp: Very strong, easily acquired, natural look ;Leather: Strong, stiff, doesn't fray ;Yarn: Various colors, cheap, flexible
==4. Know the basic knots used in macramé. Know two variations of each of these knots. == ===Overhand Knots=== {| border=0 width=100% |- |[[File:Macrame overhand.jpg|thumb|250px|Overhand knot]] |[[File:Macrame overhand on anchor.jpg|thumb|250px|Overhand knot tied onto an anchor]] |- |[[File:Macrame multiple overhand.jpg|thumb|250px|Multiple overhand knot]] |} ===Square Knots=== {| border=0 width=100% |- |[[File:Macrame square knot.jpg|thumb|250px|Square knot]] |[[File:Macrame double knot.jpg|thumb|250px|Double knot]] |} ===Half Hitches=== {| border=0 width=100% |- |[[File:Macrame half hitch left.jpg|thumb|250px|Half hitch with loop to the left]] |[[File:Macrame half hitch right.jpg|thumb|250px|Half hitch with loop to the right]] |- |[[File:Macrame alternating half hitch.jpg|thumb|250px|Alternating half hitches]] |} ===Clove Hitches=== {| border=0 width=100% |- |[[File:Macrame clove hitch left.jpg|thumb|250px|Clove hitch with loops to the left]] |[[File:Macrame clove hitch right.jpg|thumb|250px|Clove hitch with loops to the right]] |- |[[File:Macrame clove hitch upwards.jpg|thumb|250px|Clove hitch with loops up]] |- |[[File:Macrame clove hitch horizontal.jpg|thumb|250px|Clove hitch on a horizontal anchor]] |[[File:Macrame clove hitch vertical.jpg|thumb|250px|Clove hitch on a vertical anchor]] |}
===Lark's Heads=== {| border=0 width=100% |- |[[File:Macrame larks head.jpg|thumb|250px|Lark's head]] |[[File:Macrame reverse larks head.jpg|thumb|250px|Reverse Lark's head]] |} ===Single Hitches=== {| border=0 width=100% |- |[[File:Macrame single hitch left.jpg|thumb|250px|Single hitch, left-handed]] |[[File:Macrame single hitch right.jpg|thumb|250px|Single hitch, right-handed]] |}
===Macramé Knots=== {| border=0 width=100% |- |[[File:Macrame left hand knot.jpg|thumb|250px|Left-hand macramé knot]] |[[File:Macrame right hand knot.jpg|thumb|250px|Right-hand macramé knot]] |- |[[File:Macrame one and a half.jpg|thumb|250px|One-and-a-half macramé knots]] |[[File:Macrame right hand spiral.jpg|thumb|250px|Right-hand spiral knot]] |} ===Josephine Knots=== {| border=0 width=100% |- |[[File:Macrame josephine.jpg|thumb|250px|Josephine knot]] |[[File:Macrame whale knot.jpg|thumb|250px|Whale knot]] |}
==5. How is the overhand knot useful in macramé? == Overhand knots can be used to tie two cords together at the bottom of a piece, to fasten a cord to a bead or pearl, or to serve as a decorative knot in the pattern.
==6. How much cord is needed to reach the desired length of the finished product? == The length of cord needed for a finished product is directly dependent on the types of knots used. It also depends on how much knotting is done on a given cord. Anchor cords will have fewer (if any) knots compared to working cords. A general rule of thumb is to allow yourself five times more cord than the length of the product. A better guideline is to experiment. Tie a short section (at least a couple of inches (10 cm) long). Measure it, and then untie it and measure the amount of cord used. If 2 inches of your sample required 12 inches of cord, you will need six times as much cord.
==7. Make a sampler wall hanging using the essential knots and using at least two variations, such as the horizontal half-hitch, vertical half-hitch, or the half knot.== ==8. Make two other items of your choice using the square knot, the double half-hitch, and two variations of either or both items. == ==References==
[[Category:Adventist Youth Honors Answer Book|{{SUBPAGENAME}}]]

{{DISPLAYTITLE: }} [[File:Meter stamp catalog logo.jpg|800px|center]] == Welcome! == [[File:Vatican stamp type A1 with frame.jpg|right|480px]]
{{drop|P }}ostage meters first appeared experimentally at the end of the 19th century and came into general use worldwide starting in the 1920s. By the 1960s more mail was being franked by postage meter than with traditional adhesive stamps. The trend continues today as mechanical postage meters are displaced by newer and more versatile digital franking systems and machines. This is a catalog of all the different types of postage meter stamps ever used to frank mail in the world. It organizes and categorizes the stamps by their appearance (design format) rather than the meter model that printed them. It is thus a STAMP catalog for use primarily by stamp collectors and is not a meter (machine) catalog. It is an expansion of The International Postage Meter Stamp Catalog, written and published by Joel Hawkins and Rick Stambaugh in 2005, and its 2008 Supplement. [[File:New Zealand stamp type A7a.jpg|right|200px]] '''Comments, suggested changes, corrections, and additions to the catalog are encouraged. Email: rickstambaugh@gmail.com'''

revision.text:
== Welcome message == Hello, and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]! Here are some tips to [[Help|help]] you get started: * To learn the wiki-markup-language syntax, see [[Help:Editing]]. * Make sure to sign your posts and comments with four tildes, like this: ~~~~ **There is a box at the top of the edit window (if javascript is enabled on your browser) that will insert it too (looks like part of a signature). This will let others know who left it, and make it easy to reply back to you. * Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * You can tell the community something about yourself in your userpage. ** You can get to this page by clicking the tab at the top of the page labeled with your registered username. * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. ([[WB:WIW|What is Wikibooks]]). * If you are a '''Wikipedian''', see [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikipedians]] for a primer on how things work here (it's a little different). ** If you want to base your work here on materials from Wikipedia, please use [[WB:RFI]]. * If you're an '''instructor''' and plan on using Wikibooks for a class project, see [[Wikibooks:Guidelines for class projects]] * Please say hello at the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]] with any questions or ideas. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Help us by participating in policy and guideline creation. ** Please take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] before starting a new book. * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun! You will find more resources in [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you want to ask a question, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]], [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]] or [[User_talk:Panic2k4|ask me personally on my talk page]]. For site news, see the [[WB:BB|Bulletin board]]. It might be a good idea to add that page to your "[[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]]" so that you can see when any new information is posted there. You can do that by clicking the tab labeled "watch" at the top of the page. Good luck! --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 03:10, 5 August 2009 (UTC) :Hi Panic, Thanks for your welcome to Wikibooks. I could use guidance with two issues: how to upload images and place them on the page, and how to create 'chapters' and link them to the introduction/table of contents. Thanks, Rick == Image Uploading == I got you email, for uploading images into the project you should prefer using [http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Main_Page Commons] (you can use the images from there). You can also get more insight in the why this is best from the discussion going on on the [[Wikibooks:Reading_room/General#Restriction_of_image_uploads]].
To upload an image to Commons use [http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Commons:Upload the Commons upload page] it is easy and has a lot more information on how to proceed.
For info on using images see [[Editing Wikitext/Pictures]] if you still can do what you intend make a post into the in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room/Technical Assistance]] (you can use your sandbox, see above about it, to do the tests). PS: remember to sign your posts :) Hope this helps... --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 07:18, 7 August 2009 (UTC) == Copyright problems with [[:{{#ifeq:{{NAMESPACE:File:Belgium K2.jpg}}||File:File:Belgium K2.jpg|File:Belgium K2.jpg}}]] == {{mbox|type=warning|msg= Thank you for uploading [[:{{#ifeq:{{NAMESPACE:File:Belgium K2.jpg}}||File:File:Belgium K2.jpg|File:Belgium K2.jpg}}]]. Some copyright information is needed for compliance with [[w:copyright|copyright law]] and Wikibooks' [[WB:MEDIA|media policy]]. Files with incomplete or incorrect copyright information '''may soon be deleted'''. Please add copyright and source information on the [[:{{#ifeq:{{NAMESPACE:File:Belgium K2.jpg}}||File:File:Belgium K2.jpg|File:Belgium K2.jpg}}|description page]] by using Wikibooks' [[WB:FILES|copyright templates]]; there is no need to upload files again. See '''[[Help:Uploading files]]''' for help and [{{fullurl:Special:Log/upload|user={{PAGENAMEE}}}} your file uploads]. If you have any questions, feel free to contact me, or ask in the [[WB:HELP|assistance reading room]]. Thank you. [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''Unusual? Quite''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 13:26, 1 October 2009 (UTC)}} :I see you have added "Permission" and then your name to the image. This isn't what you need to do. You need to attach the license you are releasing the image under - please see [[WB:MEDIA]] for guidance. [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''Unusual? Quite''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 07:46, 2 October 2009 (UTC) : I am new at this. I don't even know how to reply to messages. I hope this (editing the narrative) is the correct way. I just replaced "{{Richard Stambaugh}}" with this "{{PD-Richard Stambaugh}}" for the image under question. Thanks for the help. Rick ::Hi, the way to do it is like this "Permission= {{PD-user|[[User:Rickstambaugh|Richard Stambaugh]]}}". I've changed this now for you. Thanks. [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''Unusual? Quite''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 20:57, 2 October 2009 (UTC) == Formatting == When categorising [[International Postage Meter Stamp Catalog/Finland]] I did some formatting that I wanted to bring to your attention. I replaced the multiple newlines (which won't display consistently) with {{tlx|clear}} and removed the font tags that colour text blue. That colour coincides with the default link colour and can therefore be confusing. It would be better to use book-wide style-sheets that will hopefully soon be implemented. --[[User:Swift|Swift]] ([[User talk:Swift|talk]]) 19:53, 22 February 2010 (UTC) == Great Job == Great job, Rick! We, at [[w:ru:Википедия:Проект:Филателия|Philately Project]] of Russian Wikipedia, appreciate very much your 'opus magnum' and look forward to being able to enjoy the Soviet Union and Russia sections of the Postage Meter Stamp Catalog. Could you prioritize that? Maybe we would even be able to add something on the subject. BTW I have a small collection of Soviet postage meter stamps of the 1970-ies. Eventually it would be nice to have the Catalog translated into Russian in ru.wikibooks.org, what do you think? Sincerely, Leonid Dzhepko. --[[User:Л.П. Джепко|Л.П. Джепко]] ([[User talk:Л.П. Джепко|talk]]) 08:30, 27 February 2010 (UTC) Hi Leonid, Yes I can re-prioritize countries and will do Russia and USSR out of my usual sequence. I appreciate help from people who know more than I do and look forward to your input. I am in the middle of France which will probably take me another two weeks. I then must do the United States for an earlier request. The U.S. could take me a long time, maybe two months. I will do Russia and Soviet Union after the U.S. That will be about May-June. Best regards, Rick : OK, thank you! D'you know that you can add yr signature automatically by clicking the button 'Your signature with timestamp' from the middle of the row right above this editing window? --[[User:Л.П. Джепко|Л.П. Джепко]] ([[User talk:Л.П. Джепко|talk]]) 15:29, 27 February 2010 (UTC) No I didn't. Thanks for the tip. I just printed out the guide to Wiki markup buttons. Maybe this will speed up my editing.--[[User:Rickstambaugh|Rickstambaugh]] ([[User talk:Rickstambaugh|talk]]) 15:34, 27 February 2010 (UTC) : Hi Rick, I notice that you have made Russia and USSR. Thank you for both, they are very informative. Hopefully, you would not mind my minor clarifications/changes regarding your wording (which I dare to make based on my knowledge of Russian and Ukrainian). If you have any questions, please feel free to contact me or change them if you do not agree. Rgds, Leonid Dzhepko. --[[User:Л.П. Джепко|Л.П. Джепко]] ([[User talk:Л.П. Джепко|talk]]) 12:30, 16 September 2010 (UTC) :: Rick, I cannot identify in yr catalogue a USSR meter stamp, which can be seen [http://www.mirmarok.ru/prim/view_article/267/ there] (machine # 9508; 7th image from top). --[[User:Л.П. Джепко|Л.П. Джепко]] ([[User talk:Л.П. Джепко|talk]]) 07:07, 17 September 2010 (UTC) == CheckUser nomination == :As an active member of the Wikibooks community, we'd like your input on the CheckUser nomination for Thenub314, which can be found [[Wikibooks:Requests_for_permissions#Thenub314.C2.A0.28talk.C2.A0.7C.C2.A0email.C2.A0.7C.C2.A0contribs.C2.A0.7C.C2.A0logs.C2.A0.7C.C2.A0rights.29_.28CheckUser.29|here]]. – [[User:Adrignola|Adrignola]] [[User talk:Adrignola|talk]] 19:52, 19 August 2010 (UTC) == West Indies == Hi Rick, New to wikibooks, so still finding out how to approach things. I'm editor of the British West Indies Study Circle Bulletin (www.bwisc.org) and personally a keen collector of Jamaica (and philatelic author). Our recent journal made mention of you wikibook and I may receive a trickle of information (one so far)which I will share with you. However, I have produced something for Jamaica myself http://www.jamaicaphilately.info/80_Meter-Marks/Jamaica_Meter-Marks.pdf and seek your advice on how you would like me proceed with it (if at all). Regards Steve
